content.body: Oh jeez, they had to use the one frame where I look like a drunk hobo as the poster: http://blog.siliconvalley-codecamp.com/2010/10/12/presentation-horror-stories/
anyone going to AEA San Diego?

Good article on Ars Technica about mobile advertising company using html 5 local storage to create a really persistent database on iOS devices: http://arstechnica.com/apple/news/2010/09/rldguid-tracking-cookies-in-safari-database-form.ars
Yeah, that's probably exploiting the same combination of tracking devices as the supercookie.
Probably
is microdata implemented anywhere yet?
that reminds me, i really should watch The Castle
good movie
supposedly :)
heycam: google search supports it, dunno about others
k
just wondering about it from the DOM perspective, though
last i heard getItems hasnt landed anywhere yet.
heycam: not aware of any dom implementations yet
from the IRI meeting
"4. Next steps: Larry: let's see if we can get more attendees & agenda items for next interim meeting."
sounds like a useful meeting
aren't they all
zcorpan: re http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=10419#c7 , value->defaultValue has proven really unpopular, which is why i am skeptical of doing it for that one
what i really want is an attribute where we can stick all the "initial state" stuff
default playback rate, volume, muted... except only support muted for now
i guess autoplay is already its own thing
and automute doesn't really sound right
i dunno, having to type defaultmuted="" defaultvolume="0.5" defaultplaybackrate="2" seems more annoying than muted="" volume="0.5" playbackrate="2"
i agree
not sure what to do
pointers to defaultValue unpopularity?
(would it be less unpopular if the attribute was called defaultvalue=""?)
search for "The HTML DOM got this very wrong" in http://lists.whatwg.org/htdig.cgi/whatwg-whatwg.org/2010-September/028755.html
it would be less unpopular with sicking if value="" was the default value and editing muted the DOM
i'm not personally convinced that's great either though
mutated
not muted :-)
the other thing is that this isn't an attribute whose values are "muted" and "not muted", it's an attribute whose values are "mute initially in all cases" and "use the user's default for this video"
foolip: what do you think? ^
so "muted" isn't necessarily the most obvious name
it should also be pointed out that a lot of people don't think we should have the mute/volume state be remembered on a per-video basis
from the author's perspective, he mutes the video if he adds the attribute
and that instead we should have a browser-level mute (maybe per tab) that can't be controlled by JS, and that video.muted should only be the author override for the video
sure
but that would make the video's mute indicator and the system mute indicator not be the only indicators of relevance, instead adding at least one more to the mix
it seems end users would want to mute a video, but not necessarily want to unmute it
which i'm not sure is a good idea
end users?
or authors?
so having muted just be an author thing seems fine to me
forgot .muted currently reflects the end user setting
i almost never want videos muted personally, if i want audio off i want all audio off and turn it off at the system level
yeah me too
I think .muted should just turn into an author setting
like it is for Flash video as well

i'd love a "this tab is a source of sound" indicator, but i don't think i care about turning the sound off at that level (though a shortcut to override all the <video> elements on the page in one go mighht be ok)
mute control on youtube can say it should give sound, but I often have it turned off system wide anyway
sometimes, I want to mute manually
i don't understand, are you saying that .muted should not reflect the muted indicator you get from controls=""?
when a website is playing a sound and I can't figure out how to stop it
I'd like browsers to provide some UI to find which tabs are currently playing some sound
Hixie: on a second thought, maybe it's not so bad to just mutate the dom
Hixie, I guess in that case mutating the DOM might be ok, though I am not sure
Hixie, for <details> UAs could remember the state too which would mutate the DOM
i think mutating the dom would be really weird for the reason given by the CSS example I gave in http://lists.whatwg.org/htdig.cgi/whatwg-whatwg.org/2010-September/028755.html
(that problem isn't such a big deal for <details>)
why is it weird? if the author wants special styling for muted videos, it makes sense to have video[muted] match when the video is muted
isn't it the same problem for <details>?
author assumes it is open/closed but it's the other way around based on earlier interaction (or maybe a preference/extension that expands all those controls by default)
i would expect a difference because an author might have a bunch of muted videos that are always muted, and he uses that as a hook for styling them differently from the main video that isn't muted
e.g. imagine if the small poster frames on a youtube page were all live <video>s
muted ones
and they were made small because all muted videos were small
that's different than <details> and [open] because the most likely reason to style [open] is that you're trying to do something for when it's open vs when it's not
but i agree that this argument is weak

it seems stupid to hook that styling off muted="", and anyway youtube would want to use a different video stream for those to save bandwidth, and could just remove the audio stream altogether and not bother with muted=""
yeah i'm not saying it'd be a good idea
what if the author only has the main video and wants to style it specially when it's muted
we could introduce :muted for that, but having [muted] just work is simpler
that argues for exposing the entire API in content attributes
i'm not sure that's a reasonable line of argumentation
true
fwiw, flash apparently makes a mess of this particular issue (muting by default), so they're not useful as inspiration here.
the styling would only be affected if the user agent remembered the muted settings, I wonder how likely such a scenario is
annevk: it seems like better user experience to remember the mute setting on reload
is it worth the trouble?
however, having muted and .defaultMuted also works for me
zcorpan is right that defaultmuted="" is kinda ugly
annevk: remembering checkbox states is apparently worth the trouble
although a form taken together can take a long time to fill, while muting a video is trivial
so i dunno
i'm not an UX guy :)
s/an/a/
Hixie, I meant following the <input value> design
ah
sicking would hate that
Hixie, sicking is right that it's not nice, but it would be internally consistent and somewhat predictable
and not give weird DOM stuff
thinks that remembering mute state may be more important for some settings than remembering checked state, btw :-)
(though in the case of <details> it would require a pseudo-class of some kind to be introduced)
yeah, <details> is kind of my experiment in this space
i want to see what authors think of the straight-DOM-mutation design
seems bad to ship Hixie experiments with known bad design that are impossible to revert later on
if it is bad design
can't we already test this since some versions of ie mutate the dom?
well it's not known bad, that's the point
the IE experiment suggested it might be good, but was confused because authors were more annoyed with the lack of interop than either particular behaviour.
maybe we can get help from the html5 doctors here
post a simplequiz
Which Way Sucks Less?
might be interesting
summons the doctors
that would certainly be interesting, but it's more the organic blog rants and how many pages use it and so on that i am interested in
e.g. finding how many people use [open] vs how many people detect onopen and set a class or whatnot
that would be a function of what works in existing browsers
yes
it's a long-term experiment
so when we know the answer it's too late to change the feature
yeah, <details> is stuck this way forever.
the point is to find out the results for future ideas.
well, <details> is not stuck yet
hsivonen, how does the parser know the difference between network and document.write() characters?
annevk: What are you reading?
Presumably the "script nesting level" is non-zero when processing document.written characters
the <meta http-equiv> thing
that is a good point
not necessiraly
necessarily
consider document.write('<script src=""></script><meta ...>');
also note crazy things like <script>document.write('<script src=""></script><meta');</script> http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html;charset=gah">
annevk: data that has come from document.write is in a different queue of buffers than data that has come from the network
Well it isn't even clear to me what behaviour hsivonen wants for the latter case :)
annevk: when the parser parses the data and generates tree operations, the informantion about where the element came from is baked into the op code
jgraham: I want to ignore the meta if the > character that caused the token to be emitted came from document.write
Hixie: Is there some clear explaination of the *point* of the script nesting level concept? I can follow things through the algorithm but I don't have an intuitive sense of why it is needed
in Hixie's document.write('<script src=""></script><meta ...>');
example, the meta came from document.write
in Hixie's next example, it didn't
hsivonen, that sounds like implementation details
annevk: we're always speccing details
For example I can't instantly see why the script nesting level would be 0 for the meta in the first example
annevk: I want my details to be specced so that I don't need to change anything
hsivonen, I guess I'm saying it would be nice to not have this one, but the "script nesting level" makes sense
(I assume it would be 0 from context)
jgraham: it's just used to keep track of when the parser should be unblocked in the case of the parser getting blocked during a re-entrant document.write()

jgraham: e.g. if you document.write() a script that document.write()s an external script, the parser should not be unblocked by the second por third nested parsers, only the first (not-nested) parser.
Currently, Gecko doesn't differentiate between elements that originated from tokens that came from synchronous document.write tokenization and that came from asynchronous document.write tokenizations
feels like a diagram would help here
i just noticed that the description of http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=11013 doesn't match the summary
for the record, i don't read the summaries generally
so please don't put important information in the summaries :-)
(i similarly don't read subject lines in e-mails)
ok bed time
nn
ooh. Decisions.
Hixie: did you mean to have the link continue to the end of the paragraph in r5618?
oh, Simon is gone
zcorpan, if there's logs, it looked good otherwise
http://vimeo.com/15775937 -- howcome on CSS
kind a like that original World Wide Web slogan he shows
"you click, we do the rest!"
http://people.opera.com/howcome/2008/talks/tour/cern-2853749.jpg
a
annevk: is Greg Wilkins from opera?
no
(or rather, where is he from)
I can't recall.
Presumably from Webtide ("the java experts behind jetty")
k
http://www.webtide.com/about/management.jsp
huh http://images.vizworld.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/Apple-Flash-Infographics.jpg
hmm, [Supplemental] does not work for constructor additions
annevk: status on publications is that I have been traveling and I will attempt to get everything ready for publication on Thursday
but if not, it will be next Tuesday instead
hey MikeSmith, wb then :)
should have realized you were away
I'm going to be in and out this week as well
I'm in Australia at the Web Directions South event
aah, good times
and some other things around that
emailed you one question about TPAC
yep
just replied
kk
as far as I'm concerned publishing next week is fine
was just wondering what the holdup was
holdup is me as usual :)
jgraham: looks like it got fixed
Did Opera submit their WebSockets tests anywhere?
Ms2ger, they're up for grabs
Ms2ger, guess one of us ought to email public-webapps...
Ms2ger: They often depend on th -76 protocol. Also they require pywebsockets which is not sutiable for public-facing servers
So whilst we encourage people implemening -76 (really: -00) to use the tests, it's not clear that they are in a state where they should be submitted anywhere
should really get around to write the node.js powered websocket protocol tests.
At least dump them on www-archive, then
Sure, we can send a link to www-archive
wishes for a bot to ask zcorpan to do that when he returns
hopes that zcorpan reads the logs with bot-like diligence
the WebKit layout tests also have a bunch of WebSocket tests
(I am not sure how many would be useful as standards tests of the protocol)
othermaciej: Presumably in specs-theory-land we curenly dn't want tests of the protocol, only of the API
Of course it is hard to test the API without some assumptions about the protocol
Presumably the point of the WHATWG was to get out of specs-theory-land
right, and we made the tests public :)
sends jgraham a cake
I guess webapps can take the tests that we have and adapt them for the new protocol if it happens
sicking, how could I provide a diff that takes me from one version of the patch to another, when there's no common base commit that both patches will apply to?
(Also, do I have to do anything now on the bug, or someone else will handle everything and I can forget about it for now?)
is still of opinion that when we have a spec X vs spec Y discussion, there should be PoC's made and tested.
AryehGregor: add "checkin-needed" keyword
AryehGregor: for dealing with merge conflicts interdiffs are indeed hard to produce
AryehGregor: basically what you'd do in this case is:
1. update to tip
PoCs? I guess not Pieces of Cake, although I am avaliable to test cake if needed
2. make necessary changes
Depending on the provenance of said cake
3. create a diff between code in 1 and 2
No horrible supermarket cake
AryehGregor: a good way to do 3, if you're using mq, is to push a new patch on the queue before you start with 2
jgraham: proof-of-concept or proof-of-code
What does "make necessary changes" mean?
AryehGregor: well, in this case no changes were needed
Fix review comments, I guess
AryehGregor: but otherwise make whatever changes are needed to make things work on tip

micheil: You are free to do that of course; don' feel you have to ask permission. And I encourage it; it would be very useful. Although it can't settle many interesting questions, like relative securiy properties or deployability on large scales
sicking, so how is that different from just a new version of the patch?  My v3 was just the same exact patch as v2 but with conflicts resolved.
AryehGregor: in this case simply answering "yes" to my question if the only thing you changed was to remove the HTMLObjectElement changes would have been enough :)
Okay.
jgraham: true, but it'd weed out the specs that don't aid the protocol.
micheil: I don' really know what you mean "don't aid the protocol"
It might be helpful for answering certain specific questions
I'm not sure either there. I'm just saying that it'd be good to see something being done in code rather then just theory.
But it's hard to see how to use it to assess the relative importance of obfuscating all user-supplied data for security vs making routing using extant HTTP infrastructure possible, for example
Which is the current big issue
Note that I am not trying o discourage you; making rough implementations of draft specs is one of my favourite ways to beter understand those specs
jgraham: well, I'll probably be implementing a -02 parse for packets soon.
just got big problems in my new -00 parser first.
hmmm not interop for lastModified between browsers  http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/dom.html#dom-document-lastmodified
I tried on a page without LastModified defined at the HTTP level.
javascript:alert(document.lastModified)
Opera 10.63 - January 1, 1970 GMT
Safari 5.0.2 - Nil
Firefox 4.0b6 - 10/13/2010 14:36:31 (date of the cache)
"If the last modification date and time are not known, the attribute must return the current date and time in the above format."
what's the deal with motion jpeg?
i tried reading up on it and i'm wondering how it originally got supported? and is it formally discouraged/depreciated somewhere?
and if not what's the case for not allowing it to be used in conjunction with the video tag?
in http://www.w3.org/2002/09/wbs/40318/issues-74-and-105-objection-poll/ how are #2 and #3 different?
othermaciej? ^
Hixie: I read them, and I assume there's some subtle point that I don't get.  I just gave the same objection to both.
lsxq, the spec allows it, but nobody has implemented it
this poll seems very poorly constructed
Hixie: I dunno, looks like a bug in the poll
Oh, wait, wrong one.  I havent' answered that.
I believe one of questions 2 or 3 is redundant and should be deleted
chrome v6.0.472.63 - Nil
Ms2ger: so i guess i should be complaining to browser vendors then?
ok only IE8 gives what the spec says (or maybe the spec says what IE8 does)
lsxq: Yup, if you want it that's the course to take.
lsxq, you could try
lsxq: There's probably little interest in supporting it for web video since its compression performance is very poor
Hixie: Sam removed the dupe

Philip`: i'm definitely not going to argue with that, it's just that even the newer browsers have added in mjpeg playback under and well.. it's really video right? doesn't it make sense to be able to use it under the video tag?
k
lsxq, do you also think animated GIF should be supported in <video>?
In theory, maybe, but nobody does, I don't think.
well you can't stream gif like you can mjpeg.. i don't think
annevk: yt?
Hixie, somewhat
Hixie, if you wonder about CSSOM View, my idea is to add the UA-agnostic stuff for scrolling
Hixie, elsewhere it also deals with other media (usually simply returning zero) zo it can do that here too
is enjoying Twin Peaks
annevk: k
annevk: sounds good
annevk: do you want me to do anything with the text currently in HTML? e.g. archive it in the bug and assign the bug to you?
that sounds good
k
thanks
annevk: btw is there a magical invocation i can use to use the scroll into view stuff?
for frag id nav
also, please put a link to the dev.w3.org version on the TR/ version, i can never find the editor's draft and the TR/ draft has higher pagerank
oh, i see, "scroll the element into view [CSSOMVIEW]" should do it
Hixie, Bert removes those links when publishing
Hixie, apparently that is within his rights and I have been so far the only person to vocally argue against it within the CSS WG
I've never had a draft on TR with the dev links removed, or else I'd argue against it too.
annevk: refuse to publish again until he backs down

I'm not sure how not having published anything yet is relevant. Either it is useful or it is not. The relevant thread is http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Member/w3c-css-wg/2010JulSep/thread.html#msg43 (W3C Member-only; no idea why)
the whole TR/ page is such an anachronism
Hixie, I get enough trouble as it is within the CSS WG, but this is one of the reasons CSSOM hasn't been published at all yet
get into*
annevk: well if you don't publish on the TR/ page at all, my life is easier cos i can't find the TR/ one by mistake :-)
so that works for me :-)

i think it's ludicrous that the IETF publishes its specs in a manner that is optimised for 1970s-era line printers and the W3C publishes its specs in a manner optimised for 1980s-style closed-room development
s/closed-room/magazine publishing/
IETF's spec publishing actively angers me.  It feels like they are slapping me in the face every time I look at one.
oh i wouldn't take the IETF's practices personally
it says more about their community than about how they feel about other communities
Hixie: That's because most of the IETF members still use 1970s-era line printers
lol
IETF doesn't have members actually
they have a model more like the WHATWG than the W3C
The only thing I can possibly see it saying about their community is that every person in it uses ancient terminals.  That's not true, so I consider it an insult every time.
TabAtkins: Every person with some clout does, apparently
All those people are clearly senile and useless.
TabAtkins: no it just says that they are stuck in their ways, not that they think it's actually sensible
We discussed this like a year ago, when someone posted a link to discussion and remarked that Julian was the voice of sanity there

Hixie: There is a difference between "this isn't great, but shrug, it's kinda tradition" and "let's just screw everyone in the face every time they look at what we produce, because we can!  Bwahahahaha!".
TabAtkins: i've never heard any IETF people actually say that the lien printer thing makes sense, they're just institutionally stuck
Let's see...
TabAtkins: i don't think i've seen any evidence that anyone holds the latter opinion. I've only heard the former one, even from old timers in the IETF.
but frankly i think the text thing is just quirky, it's not harmful. What's harmful is the snapshot-style development.
My point was that the current setup is *so* bad, that you can't actually hold the former opinion.
I distinctly remember people arguing that ascii plain text was the only format with the necessary longetivity
Anyway this is just another example of standards organisations being a product of the era in which they are set up
and IETF is even worse than W3C there, because they don't even require a CR-like phase in theory
(w3c doesn't require it in practice, but at least they require it in theory)
jgraham: i feel like it's more like they're hte product of the era before the era they were set up in
jgraham: IETF was set up in the late 80s, not the early 70s
Unicode is impossible: http://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/ietf/current/msg60589.html
NRoff is easy and sane and everything else is hard: http://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/ietf/current/msg60573.html
i don't think the text/plain stuff is that bad. The real problem is that they page their specs, IMHO.
s/page/paginate/

Maybe that's because they adopt the stuff from the previous decade as "immutable stuff that will always stay with us" and treat anything too new as dangerous to their credibility now they are a fledgling standards organisation looking to be taken seriously
most RFCs nowadays are written as XML that can be converted to a variety of formats
jgraham: yeah
The pagination thing sucks so badly it hurts
jgraham: which is funny given the point is to improve standards :)
anyway
Well probably all the kids now wonder why WHATWG doesn't publish its specs in twitter-sized chunks using flash. Or something.
is not very down with the kids
Semantics are crap: http://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/ietf/current/msg60581.html

jgraham: I think it is more a question of community and habits, processes which are being carved by the cowpath. Things which are written sealed practices for the good or the bad. Both actually. It is visible in any community practices.
Dashiva: you have successfully convinced me that the IETF has crazies
It is not that surprising that the IETF has crazies, after all the world has crazies and anyone can join
The problem is, the crazies are winning
jgraham: we did use twitter. When they changed their API the twitter stuff broke and nobody complained. So the kids probably don't want that after all. :-)
If Hixie is convinced I guess I don't have to force my self to read more mails :)
Hixie: No I meant one 140 characterconformance requirement at a time
hsivonen: yt?
hsivonen: should "a style sheet that is blocking scripts", when it's from an ancestor browsing context, be required to be inserted by a parser also?
"Using HTML or PDF for RFCs is about the same as moving from
English language RFCs to mandarin language RFCs"
This stuff is comedy gold
Actually I wish I hadn't read any more of that thread
It becomes somewhat scary
annevk: Well, I commented.
ta
http://toki-woki.net/p/scroll-clock/
similar to the text-editor-made-of-radio-buttons i hypothesised about in the canvas a11y thread and got ridiculed for
I could make it in pure CSS.  ^_^
Just figure out the animations necessary for each element as it cycles through the 10 digits, then apply it to each place with successively longer animation-durations.
heh
is it intentional that vorbis_synthesis_init returns > 0 on error? (https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=604067#c3)
